intro: Chaerophyllum temulum var. canescens, commonly known as the hairy chaerophyllum, is a flowering plant native to parts of Europe and western Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes familiar plants like carrots and parsley. The plant is characterized by its finely divided, feathery leaves and small, greenish-white flowers that appear in umbels. It typically grows in moist, calcareous soils and is often found in meadows and along stream banks. Due to its delicate appearance and ecological importance, it is considered a species of conservation concern in some regions.
